metadata.name: Persuasive Communications
metadata.description: Concepts for marketing, advertising, public relations, and persuasive communication. Covers the full spectrum from ethical transparent marketing through to manipulation, propaganda, and information warfare. Explicitly models deceptive patterns to enable detection. Substrate-independent for human marketers, AI content generators, or automated influence systems.
metadata.author: hatcat-team

candidates.definition: Communication designed to influence beliefs, attitudes, or behaviors of an audience
candidates.definition_source: Synthesized from communication studies, rhetoric, and marketing disciplines

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Persuasive communication exists on a spectrum from transparent to deceptive

positive_examples: The marketing campaign highlighted product benefits
PR team crafted messaging to shape public perception
Advertisement designed to drive purchase intent
Agent generating promotional content for audience engagement
negative_examples: Technical documentation explaining how to use the product
training_hints.disambiguation: Communication intended to influence, not purely inform

candidates.definition: Marketing practices that are honest, transparent, and respect audience autonomy

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Ethical marketing respects autonomy and truth

positive_examples: Accurate product claims backed by evidence
Transparent pricing with no hidden fees
training_hints.disambiguation: Marketing that respects truth and autonomy

candidates.definition: Clear articulation of genuine benefits and value a product or service provides

positive_examples: Our tool saves 10 hours per week on data entry
This solves the specific problem of X

candidates.definition: Marketing claims that are verifiable, honest, and not misleading
Providing sufficient information for audience to make autonomous decisions

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Informed choice relates to valid consent

positive_examples: Here are the pros and cons
This may not be right for everyone
negative_examples: Act now before it's too late

candidates.definition: Real experiences from actual users shared with appropriate disclosure

positive_examples: Real customer Jane shares her experience
Disclosure: I received this product for free

candidates.definition: Transparent communication of commercial relationships, sponsorships, and material connections

positive_examples: I'm an affiliate and earn commission

candidates.definition: Communication that deceives, exploits psychological vulnerabilities, or undermines rational decision-making

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Core deception category requiring monitoring

training_hints.disambiguation: Deceptive or exploitative influence, not honest persuasion

candidates.definition: False or inaccurate information spread without deliberate intent to deceive

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: False information regardless of intent

positive_examples: Sharing an article without checking if it's true
Repeating a rumor believing it to be fact

candidates.definition: Deliberately false information spread with intent to deceive or manipulate

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Core deception concept requiring critical monitoring

positive_examples: Fabricated news story to influence opinion

candidates.definition: Systematic communication designed to influence attitudes on political or ideological issues, often bypassing rational evaluation

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Propaganda often relies on manipulation and emotional bypass

positive_examples: State-sponsored messaging to shape public opinion
Demonization of outgroup to build support
Repetition of slogans to normalize ideas

candidates.definition: Creating fake grassroots movements or artificial appearance of organic public support

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Astroturfing is fundamentally deceptive about source

positive_examples: Paid commenters pretending to be organic users
Sock puppet accounts creating illusion of consensus

candidates.definition: User interface designs that trick users into actions against their interests

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Dark patterns undermine informed consent

positive_examples: Confirm-shaming (Are you sure you don't want savings?)
Roach motel - easy to sign up, hard to cancel

candidates.definition: Exploiting cognitive biases, emotional vulnerabilities, or psychological weaknesses to influence behavior

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Exploitation of psychological vulnerabilities undermines autonomy

positive_examples: Targeting gambling ads to recovering addicts
Manipulating children's inability to distinguish ads

candidates.definition: Methods and strategies used to influence audience attitudes and behaviors

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Persuasion techniques can be used ethically or manipulatively

positive_examples: Using social proof to build credibility

candidates.definition: Using evidence of others' behavior or approval to influence decisions

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Social proof can be genuine or manufactured

training_hints.disambiguation: Claims about others' behavior or choices

candidates.definition: Creating urgency through limited availability or time pressure

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Scarcity can be real or manufactured

candidates.definition: Leveraging expert status or credentials to build credibility

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Authority can be legitimate or false

positive_examples: As seen on major news networks

candidates.definition: Creating obligation through gifts, favors, or free value
Building rapport and positive associations to increase influence

positive_examples: The brand for people who care

candidates.definition: Leveraging small commitments to lead to larger ones (foot-in-door)

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Graduated commitment can bypass deliberate consent

positive_examples: Sign up for the newsletter first
training_hints.disambiguation: Small commitments leading to larger ones

candidates.definition: Using emotional triggers rather than rational arguments to persuade

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Emotional appeals can bypass rational evaluation

candidates.definition: Using logic, evidence, and rational arguments to persuade

training_hints.disambiguation: Logic and evidence, not emotional manipulation

candidates.definition: Identifying and reaching specific audience segments with tailored messaging

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Targeting raises consent and privacy concerns

positive_examples: Targeting parents with child product ads

candidates.definition: Targeting based on demographic characteristics like age, gender, income, location

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Basic demographic targeting is generally benign

candidates.definition: Targeting based on observed behaviors, browsing history, and purchase patterns

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Behavioral tracking requires consent

candidates.definition: Targeting based on personality traits, values, attitudes, and interests

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Psychographic targeting can manipulate based on personality

training_hints.disambiguation: Personality and values based, not just interests

candidates.definition: Targeting based on content context rather than user tracking

positive_examples: Cooking product ads on recipe sites

candidates.definition: Hyper-personalized targeting that exploits individual vulnerabilities or enables manipulation at scale

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Microtargeting enables personalized manipulation

positive_examples: Different political messages to different individuals

candidates.definition: How information is presented to influence interpretation and response

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Framing can be transparent or manipulative

positive_examples: Narrative that positions product as hero
training_hints.disambiguation: Deliberate presentation choices, not neutral reporting

candidates.definition: Presenting options in terms of potential gains and benefits

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Gain framing is generally benign persuasion

positive_examples: Get more done in less time

candidates.definition: Presenting options in terms of potential losses and risks

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Loss framing can exploit loss aversion bias

training_hints.disambiguation: Emphasizing losses and risks, not gains

candidates.definition: Using storytelling structure to frame information and influence interpretation

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Narrative framing is a common communication technique

candidates.definition: Highlighting certain information while de-emphasizing or omitting other relevant information

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Selective emphasis can deceive by omission

candidates.definition: Changing how a situation or objection is perceived by presenting it differently

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Reframing is a neutral communication technique

positive_examples: It's not expensive, it's an investment
That's not a bug, it's a feature

candidates.definition: Selection and optimization of communication channels to reach and influence audience

training_hints.disambiguation: Where to communicate, not what to say

candidates.definition: Communication channels owned and controlled by the organization

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Owned media is transparent in source

candidates.definition: Coverage and mentions earned through publicity rather than paid placement

training_hints.disambiguation: Organic coverage, not paid or controlled

candidates.definition: Advertising and sponsored content placement through payment

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Paid media is transparent when properly disclosed

candidates.definition: Designing content to spread organically through sharing and social amplification

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Viral strategies can be organic or manufactured

candidates.definition: Using individuals with audience trust and reach to promote products or messages

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Influencer marketing requires disclosure to not be deceptive

candidates.definition: Strategic use of information to gain competitive, political, or military advantage

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Information warfare is adversarial manipulation at scale

candidates.definition: Paid content designed to look like editorial content or organic posts

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Native advertising can deceive about source

positive_examples: Paid article that looks like news

candidates.definition: Misleading claims about environmental responsibility or sustainability

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Greenwashing is deceptive about environmental impact

training_hints.disambiguation: False environmental claims, not genuine sustainability

candidates.definition: Superficial adoption of social justice messaging for commercial benefit without substantive action

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Wokewashing deceives about commitment to values

positive_examples: Feminist messaging with gender pay gaps
Social justice marketing by exploitative companies
training_hints.disambiguation: Superficial values messaging, not genuine commitment

candidates.definition: Using fear and anxiety to motivate action or compliance

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Fear appeals can bypass rational decision-making

positive_examples: Don't let this happen to you
training_hints.disambiguation: Exploitative fear, not legitimate risk communication

candidates.definition: Using shame, guilt, or social embarrassment to drive behavior

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Shame appeals exploit psychological vulnerabilities

training_hints.disambiguation: Using shame/guilt as leverage, not positive motivation

candidates.definition: Practices and systems that promote accurate, honest, and trustworthy information

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Information integrity is the positive opposite of deception

candidates.definition: Systematic verification of claims against evidence and authoritative sources

positive_examples: Checking if the statistic is accurate
Verifying the quote against original source
Rating claims as true, false, or misleading

candidates.definition: Confirming the origin, authenticity, and credibility of information sources
Publishing corrections, retractions, and updates when errors are discovered

positive_examples: Updating the article with accurate information
training_hints.disambiguation: Actively fixing errors, not hiding them

candidates.definition: Clear attribution of sources, methods, and basis for claims
Skills and education for critically evaluating media and information sources

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Media literacy is protective against manipulation

training_hints.disambiguation: Critical evaluation skills, not passive consumption

candidates.definition: Genuine, transparent communication and community building without manufactured authenticity

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Authentic engagement is honest by nature

positive_examples: Organic community forming around shared interest
Transparent about who we are and what we want

candidates.definition: Organic bottom-up movements and support arising from genuine public interest

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Genuine grassroots is authentic by definition

positive_examples: Real people advocating for causes they believe in

candidates.definition: Real communities of actual users or supporters with genuine shared interests
Open advocacy for positions with clear disclosure of interests and goals

positive_examples: We believe X and here's why
As a company that sells Y, we think...
Full disclosure: I have a stake in this

candidates.definition: Persuasion that is transparent about its intent to influence

positive_examples: I'm trying to convince you that...
Here's my argument for why you should...
Let me make the case for...
This is a persuasive piece, and here's my position
negative_examples: Pretending to be neutral while persuading

candidates.definition: Design practices that respect user autonomy, transparency, and wellbeing
Interface design where options, costs, and consequences are clearly visible

positive_examples: Clear explanation of what happens next

candidates.definition: Ensuring users understand what they're agreeing to before consent

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Informed consent is the positive standard for consent

positive_examples: Clear what data is collected and why

candidates.definition: Making it as easy to leave, cancel, or opt out as it was to sign up
Default settings that serve user interests rather than extracting value

training_hints.disambiguation: Defaults that help users, not exploit them

candidates.definition: Persuasion through positive emotions like hope, aspiration, and empowerment

positive_examples: You have the power to change this

candidates.definition: Communication that builds confidence and capability rather than exploiting insecurity

positive_examples: You already have what it takes
Here's how you can do this yourself
You're capable of making this decision
negative_examples: You're not good enough without this

candidates.definition: Verifiable environmental responsibility backed by real action and transparent reporting
Values-based messaging backed by consistent organizational practices and actions
Presenting information fairly including both strengths and limitations

positive_examples: Here are the pros and cons
This works well for X but not Y

candidates.definition: Personalization based on explicit user consent and preferences

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Consent-based personalization is the ethical standard

candidates.definition: Educational communication about civic institutions, processes, and participation

positive_examples: How a bill becomes a law

candidates.definition: Journalism that serves public interest through accountability, transparency, and truth-seeking

positive_examples: Following the evidence wherever it leads
